attributes.title: •	Are there Sexual Health Disparities related to Bisexual Identity among Men who have Sex with Men in Ireland?
attributes.withdrawal_justification: This pre-registration is being revised in advance of the data being received by the researchers. Proof of this will be provided in the OSF project.

attributes.title: Protocol: Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) and Western Medicine Therapies for the Novel Coronavirus Pneumonia (NCP): A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis
attributes.description:
This is a systematic review and meta-analysis. In this study, we will mainly solve the following three questions:
1. Is integrated traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) and Western medicine therapies effective for patients confirmed or suspected with 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV)? And for the prevention of 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV)? 
2. How does the efficacy of integrated traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) and Western medicine therapies compare to that with TCM therapies alone, Western medicine therapies alone, blank control, placebo control and other interventions? 
3. What moderating variables are associated with treatment efficacy in studies of traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) and Western medicine therapies for patients with 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV)? 
We have submitted our protocol to the PROSPERO and the Cochrane group. After we finished this study, we will report results and publish them in a peer-reviewed professional journal.

q1.value: Effectiveness of Integrated Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) and Western Medicine Therapies in the Prevention and Treatment of the Novel Coronavirus Pneumonia (NCP): A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis

q2.value: Hui Yang, Qinwei Fu, Lanzhi Zhang, Miao Liu, Qinxiu Zhang, Yang Liu, Xinrong Li, Yan Xie, Juan Zhong, Ying Liu, Zhiqing Liu, Li Fu

q3.value: In December 2019, a series of unexplained pneumonia cases appeared in Wuhan, Hubei province, China, with clinical manifestations very similar to viral pneumonia. Deep sequencing of samples from the lower respiratory tract revealed the discovery of a novel coronavirus, which was named the 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-ncov), and the pneumonia caused by the virus was also named the Novel Coronavirus Pneumonia (NCP) by Chinese government. So far, China has confirmed more than 40,000 cases, including health care workers, and 25 countries in Asia, Europe, North America and Oceania have confirmed hundreds of export cases. However, there are no specific drugs for the NCP, and most of the existing drugs are controversial and need further study. In the clinical treatment of the NCP in China, traditional Chinese medicine has been widely used, and there are many news reports that the combined treatment of traditional Chinese and western medicine is effective. Till now, about 30 protocols of RCTs about integrated traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) and Western medicine therapies for the NCP have been registered for implementation. There are no SR or protocol on integrated traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) and Western medicine therapies for the NCP. Therefore, research on it is very urgent.

q4.value:
1. Integrated traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) and Western medicine therapies is effective for patients confirmed or suspected with 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV), and for the prevention of the NCP.
2. How does the efficacy of integrated traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) and Western medicine therapies compare to that with TCM therapies alone, Western medicine therapies alone, blank control, placebo control and other interventions? 
3. There are some moderating variables associated with prevention and treatment efficacy in studies of traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) and Western medicine therapies for patients with the NCP.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

q7.value:
Three reviewers searched the online databases listed above and recorded the titles and abstracts of all the articles.
Three evaluators assessed the eligibility of these articles and made decisions on every research (inclusion or exclusion) independently. If they did not reach the same decision, the concerned articles were discussed with a fourth reviewer (Qinxiu Zhang).
Three reviewers extracted data independently from each study.
Differences regarding the extracted data were resolved after discussion with a fourth reviewer (Qinxiu Zhang).
Three authors of our review team will independently assess the methodological quality of included trials, and consensus will be reached by discussion with a third party in case of discrepancy.

The methodological quality of RCTs will be assessed according to the risk of bias tool described in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions [Higgins JPT 2009]. Six elements will be assessed: random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of outcome assessors, incomplete outcome data, free of selective reporting, and other bias. Disagreements will be resolved by discussion with a third party.

question.value:
1. Anticipated start date: 24/03/2020;

2. Anticipated completion date: 30/07/2020;

3.Review question: ①. Is integrated traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) and Western medicine therapies effective for patients confirmed or suspected with 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV)? And for the prevention of the NCP? 
                                   ②. How does the efficacy of integrated traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) and Western medicine therapies compare to that with TCM therapies alone, Western medicine therapies alone, blank control, placebo control and other interventions? 
                                   ③. What moderating variables are associated with treatment efficacy in studies of traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) and Western medicine therapies for patients with the NCP? 

4. Searches: English databases including PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Library and Chinese databases including CNKI, Wanfang, VIP databases will be searched. The research will start following the PRISMA protocol.

The terms used in the search will follow the rules of the Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) and the question that guided the search was based on the PICOS strategy (participants, interventions, comparison, results and studies). The following search strategy terms will be included: ①"coronavirus" or "CoV" or "Guanzhuang Bingdu(冠状病毒)"; ② "traditional Chinese medicine" or "decoction" or "herbal medicine" or "herbs " or "Chinese medicinal herb" or "Chinese patent medcine" or "granule" or "powder" or "electuary" or "pill" or "pellet" or "Keli (颗粒)" or "San (散)" or "Chongji (冲剂)" or "Wan (丸)" or "Dan (丹)" or "Zhongyao (中药)" or "Tang (汤)".
One month will be allocated for data collection and one month for article analysis.
Retrieval time is from the inception dates of the databases to 20 April, 2020.
We also considered the alternative terms and spellings for keywords.
In addition, the references of initially included literature were traced back to achieve a comprehensive search. English and Chinese language were included.

5. Condition or domain being studied: In December 2019, a series of unexplained pneumonia cases appeared in Wuhan, Hubei province, China, with clinical manifestations very similar to viral pneumonia. Deep sequencing of samples from the lower respiratory tract revealed the discovery of a novel coronavirus, which was named the 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-ncov), and the pneumonia caused by the virus was also named the Novel Coronavirus Pneumonia (NCP) by Chinese government. So far, China has confirmed more than 40,000 cases, including health care workers, and 25 countries in Asia, Europe, North America and Oceania have confirmed hundreds of export cases. However, there are no specific drugs for the NCP, and most of the existing drugs are controversial and need further study. In the clinical treatment of the NCP in China, traditional Chinese medicine has been widely used, and there are many news reports that the combined treatment of traditional Chinese and western medicine is effective. Till now, about 30 protocols of RCTs about integrated traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) and Western medicine therapies for the NCP have been registered for implementation. There are no SR or protocol on integrated traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) and Western medicine therapies for the NCP. Therefore, research on it is very urgent.

6.Participants/population: Patients confirmed or suspected with 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV), or healthy population defined by specific strategy of RCT, regardless of gender, etiology, ethnic group, severity, diagnosed with specific criteria (i.e. mention any one of criteria for diagnosis of allergic rhinitis) are eligible for inclusion.

7. Intervention(s), exposure(s): Treatment of integrated traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) and Western medicine therapies, including dosage forms of decoction of traditional Chinese medicine, granule of traditional Chinese medicine, powder of traditional Chinese medicine, electuary of traditional Chinese medicine, pill of traditional Chinese medicine, pellet of traditional Chinese medicine and other available forms. There is no limit to the treatment of Western Medicine.

8. Comparator(s)/control: Including TCM therapies alone, Western medicine therapies alone, blank control, placebo control and other interventions. Interventions in the experimental group were not included, including treatment of traditional Chinese medicine as adjuvant therapy in different dosage forms.

9. Types of study to be included: We will include randomised controlled trials (RCTs), published and unpublished, in English and Chinese.

10. Main outcome(s): ①The survival rate;
                                      ②Duration of oxygen intaking;
                                      ③Rate of severe patients;
                                      ④Duration of hospital staying;
                                      ⑤Mortality prior to hospital discharge;
                                      ⑥Mortality following hospital discharge;
                                      ⑦Total effective rate;

11. Additional outcome(s): ① Oxygenation index;
                                                ②Respiratory parameters (such as Fi O2, PaO2, PEEP and PaCO2);
                                                ③Duration of mechanical ventilation;
                                                ④Hemodynamic indicators (such as HR, CVP, and MAP);
                                                ⑤Quality of life score;

12. Data extraction (selection and coding): Three reviewers searched the online databases listed above and recorded the titles and abstracts of all the articles.
Three evaluators assessed the eligibility of these articles and made decisions on every research (inclusion or exclusion) independently. If they did not reach the same decision, the concerned articles were discussed with a fourth reviewer (Qinxiu Zhang).
Three reviewers extracted data independently from each study.
Differences regarding the extracted data were resolved after discussion with a fourth reviewer (Qinxiu Zhang).

13.Risk of bias (quality) assessment: Three authors of our review team will independently assess the methodological quality of included trials, and consensus will be reached by discussion with a third party in case of discrepancy.
The methodological quality of RCTs will be assessed according to the risk of bias tool described in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions [Higgins JPT 2009]. Six elements will be assessed: random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of outcome assessors, incomplete outcome data, free of selective reporting, and other bias. Disagreements will be resolved by discussion with a third party.

14. Strategy for data synthesis: Statistical analyses will be performed using RevMan 5.3 software (The Cochrane Collaboration).
- Pooled risk ratio (RR) with 95% confidence interval (CI) of dichotomous outcomes will be used to report effect estimate.
- Continuous data will be presented as mean difference (MD) with 95% CI. If different measurement scales are used, standardized mean difference (SMD) will be performed to analyze continuous data.
If required data are not reported, we will try to obtain data from corresponding author.
Heterogeneity will be assessed using both the χ² test and the I² statistic, and we will consider an I² value greater than 50% indicative of substantial heterogeneity.
- For I²<50%, a fixed-effect model is used.
- For I² >=50%, a random-effect model is applied.
If data permit, we plan to exclude some trials that contribuite most to the heterogeneity to see whether the result change or not.
We will also use a summary of findings table to present the main findings using GRADEpro software (The Cochrane Collaboration). Funnel plots will be generated to detect publication bias if more than 10 trials are identified to report the same outcomes. If appropriate, we will use cumulative meta-analyses. Results of meta-analyses will be visualized by forest plots. In addition, we will conduct trial sequential analysis to evaluate the meta-analyses for primary outcomes, which can reveal the required information size and potentially false results in a meta-analysis. Intention-to-treat analysis will be applied for primary outcome, if missing data from the original trials are available.

15. Analysis of subgroups or subsets: If data permitted, we plan to conduct subgroup analyses for different groups, including:
Different age of patients
Different severity of disease
Different regimen applied
Different treat time
Different acupoints selected
Combined with other interventions or not.

16. Type and method of review: intervention; Meta-analysis; Prevention; Systematic review.

17. Health area of the review : Complementary therapies; General interests; Infections; Public health; Respiratory disorders; 

18. Languages of the review: English and Chinese;

19. Dissemination plans: In addition to producing a report, a paper will be submitted to a journal in this field.

20. Keywords: Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM); Prevention; Treatment; 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV).

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

2. Intervention(s), exposure(s): Treatment of integrated traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) and Western medicine therapies, including dosage forms of decoction of traditional Chinese medicine, granule of traditional Chinese medicine, powder of traditional Chinese medicine, electuary of traditional Chinese medicine, pill of traditional Chinese medicine, pellet of traditional Chinese medicine and other available forms. 4. Types of study to be included: We will include randomised controlled trials (RCTs), published and unpublished, in English and Chinese.

Till now, about 30 protocols of RCTs about integrated traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) and Western medicine therapies for the NCP have been registered for implementation. There are no SR or protocol on integrated traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) and Western medicine therapies for the NCP. Therefore, research on it is very urgent.

6.Participants/population: Patients confirmed or suspected with 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV), or healthy population defined by specific strategy of RCT, regardless of gender, etiology, ethnic group, severity, diagnosed with specific criteria (i.e. mention any one of criteria for diagnosis of allergic rhinitis) are eligible for inclusion.

7. Intervention(s), exposure(s): Treatment of integrated traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) and Western medicine therapies, including dosage forms of decoction of traditional Chinese medicine, granule of traditional Chinese medicine, powder of traditional Chinese medicine, electuary of traditional Chinese medicine, pill of traditional Chinese medicine, pellet of traditional Chinese medicine and other available forms. There is no limit to the treatment of Western Medicine.

8. Comparator(s)/control: Including TCM therapies alone, Western medicine therapies alone, blank control, placebo control and other interventions. Interventions in the experimental group were not included, including treatment of traditional Chinese medicine as adjuvant therapy in different dosage forms.

9. Types of study to be included: We will include randomised controlled trials (RCTs), published and unpublished, in English and Chinese.

10. Main outcome(s): ①The survival rate;
                                      ②Duration of oxygen intaking;
                                      ③Rate of severe patients;
                                      ④Duration of hospital staying;
                                      ⑤Mortality prior to hospital discharge;
                                      ⑥Mortality following hospital discharge;
                                      ⑦Total effective rate;

11. Additional outcome(s): ① Oxygenation index;
                                                ②Respiratory parameters (such as Fi O2, PaO2, PEEP and PaCO2);
                                                ③Duration of mechanical ventilation;
                                                ④Hemodynamic indicators (such as HR, CVP, and MAP);
                                                ⑤Quality of life score;

12. Data extraction (selection and coding): Three reviewers searched the online databases listed above and recorded the titles and abstracts of all the articles.
Three evaluators assessed the eligibility of these articles and made decisions on every research (inclusion or exclusion) independently. If they did not reach the same decision, the concerned articles were discussed with a fourth reviewer (Qinxiu Zhang).
Three reviewers extracted data independently from each study.
Differences regarding the extracted data were resolved after discussion with a fourth reviewer (Qinxiu Zhang).

13.Risk of bias (quality) assessment: Three authors of our review team will independently assess the methodological quality of included trials, and consensus will be reached by discussion with a third party in case of discrepancy.
The methodological quality of RCTs will be assessed according to the risk of bias tool described in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions [Higgins JPT 2009]. Six elements will be assessed: random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of outcome assessors, incomplete outcome data, free of selective reporting, and other bias. Disagreements will be resolved by discussion with a third party.

14. Strategy for data synthesis: Statistical analyses will be performed using RevMan 5.3 software (The Cochrane Collaboration).
- Pooled risk ratio (RR) with 95% confidence interval (CI) of dichotomous outcomes will be used to report effect estimate.
- Continuous data will be presented as mean difference (MD) with 95% CI. If different measurement scales are used, standardized mean difference (SMD) will be performed to analyze continuous data.
If required data are not reported, we will try to obtain data from corresponding author.
Heterogeneity will be assessed using both the χ² test and the I² statistic, and we will consider an I² value greater than 50% indicative of substantial heterogeneity.
- For I²<50%, a fixed-effect model is used.
- For I² >=50%, a random-effect model is applied.
If data permit, we plan to exclude some trials that contribuite most to the heterogeneity to see whether the result change or not.
We will also use a summary of findings table to present the main findings using GRADEpro software (The Cochrane Collaboration). Funnel plots will be generated to detect publication bias if more than 10 trials are identified to report the same outcomes. If appropriate, we will use cumulative meta-analyses. Results of meta-analyses will be visualized by forest plots. In addition, we will conduct trial sequential analysis to evaluate the meta-analyses for primary outcomes, which can reveal the required information size and potentially false results in a meta-analysis. Intention-to-treat analysis will be applied for primary outcome, if missing data from the original trials are available.

15. Analysis of subgroups or subsets: If data permitted, we plan to conduct subgroup analyses for different groups, including:
Different age of patients
Different severity of disease
Different regimen applied
Different treat time
Different acupoints selected
Combined with other interventions or not.

16. Type and method of review: intervention; Meta-analysis; Prevention; Systematic review.

17. Health area of the review : Complementary therapies; General interests; Infections; Public health; Respiratory disorders; 

18. Languages of the review: English and Chinese;

19. Dissemination plans: In addition to producing a report, a paper will be submitted to a journal in this field.

20. Keywords: Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM); Prevention; Treatment; 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV).
registration_responses.q16.question: not applicable

attributes.title: Pathogenic FAM83G palmoplantar keratoderma mutations inhibit the PAWS1:CK1α association and attenuate Wnt signalling.
attributes.description: Underlying data and supplementary figures for Wu et al

summary.value: Version 2: Contains 2 additional supplementary figures and associated underlying data to address reviewer comments.

registration_responses.summary: Version 2: Contains 2 additional supplementary figures and associated underlying data to address reviewer comments.

attributes.title: Correlation of Paradigms to Assess the Descending Pain Modulation

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Correlation of Paradigms to Assess the Descending Pain Modulation

other.value: Registration is valid because the procedure was only piloted so far on 5 healthy participants.

sample.value: The expected sample size is n=40 (n=10 in each condition).

analyses.value: The results of the four trials will be compared using Pearson’s correlation coefficient (Bonferroni-corrected for multiple comparisons) and linear regressions.

outliers.value: There will be no exclusions of outliers.

dependent.value:
Pain intensity will be measured by a computerized Visual Analogue Scale (CoVAS) ranging from 0 (no pain) to 100 (worst pain imaginable). Subject will provide continuous ratings of pain intensity during all paradigms measurements.

For the Offset analgesia (OA) paradigm will include three randomized trials. Offset trials will include a 15-seconds interval of Pain50 (T1), 10 seconds at a temperature +1,5°C higher than T1 (T2), and 15 seconds at the temperature Pain50 (T3). Baseline trials will include 15-seconds of Pain50 (T1), 10 seconds at a temperature +1,5°C higher than T1 (T2), and 15 seconds at the baseline temperature (32°C, T3). Constant trials will include 40 seconds of Pain50 (T1).
For the conditioned pain modulation (CPM) paradigm, a test stimulus at the individual temperature of Pain50 will be applied to the non-dominant forearm before, during and afterward the conditioning stimulus. The conditioning stimulus will be delivered by immersion of the dominant hand in circulating cold-water at 11°C for two minutes. Participants will be asked to rate the heat pain intensity of each test stimulus continuously. 
The Spatial Summation paradigm will contain two randomized stimuli (with and without partially covered thermode head) at the Pain50 temperature for 40 seconds. For the Temporal Summation paradigm, participants will receive a series of 10 thermal stimuli at the Pain50 temperature. Each manual stimulation cycle will consist of a one-second contact interval and a two-second inter-stimulus interval. Participants will be asked to evaluate the pain intensity of the first and the 10th heat stimulus.

conditions.value: Healthy pain-free participants will be randomly assigned to one of four groups. The subjects will be experienced the fourth paradigm on the same day. Each heat stimuli will be applied to the non-dominant volar forearm.

hypothesis.value:
Q: Is there a correlation between the four pain paradigms (conditioned pain modulation, Offset Analgesia, Temporal Summation and Spatial Summation)?
H: Results of four paradigms measuring endogenous pain modulation are not correlated to each other

attributes.title: Evaluating Task Expectancy Effects on Recollection and Familiarity

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value:
Evaluating Task Expectancy Effects on Recollection and Familiarity

In this study, we will examine how expectancy effects for free recall and guessing tasks can affect recognition performance relative to a restudy control task. Expectancy effects will be encouraged through task repetitions. Recalling a study list or attempting to guess related by non-studied associates of a list has been shown to increase later recognition relative to a restudy task (i.e., retrieval-practice), but only when participants repeat recall and guessing tasks and expect them (Huff, Balota, & Hutchison, 2016; Huff, Yates, & Balota, 2018). Our study is includes a preregistered replication of these effects, but will further examine how recall and guessing expectancy processes effect recollection and familiarity phenomenology by having participants report remember/know judgments at test.

other.value:
Rate of correct free recall, as well as intrusions, will be analyzed to determine any task effects. Rate of correct guessing of critical items will also be reported, although this value is expected to be quite low. Demographics will be collected and means reported of the sample size.

Presently, data collection has been completed for Experiment 1, though the recall, guessing, and recognition data has not yet been analyzed. Data collection has just begun for Experiment 2 (less than 10 participants collected) and data have not been examined or analyzed. Data collection has not yet started for Experiment 3.

sample.value: Experiment 1 includes 81 participants. Experiments 2 and 3 will include a total of 102 participants due to the 6 counterbalanced versions of these experiments.

analyses.value:
Several 3 (Task Type: Restudy vs. Recall vs. Guess) x 3 (List Type: Unrelated vs. Ad Hoc vs. Categorized) ANOVAs will be used to determine significant differences of responses on the final recognition test across the 3 experiments.

 A 3 (Task Type: Restudy vs. Recall vs. Guess) x 3 (List Type: Unrelated vs. Ad Hoc vs. Categorized) x 2 (Recollection vs. Familiarity) ANOVA will be used to evaluate task and list type effects on recollection and familiarity. 

All significant effects reported will include effect sizes (partial-eta squared for ANOVAs, Cohen’s d for t-tests) and pBIC (Bayesian Information Criterion; Masson, 2011) for null effects reported.

outliers.value: Participants who score either above or below 2.5 SDs of the sample mean on the recognition test will be eliminated as an outlier. The 2.5 SD criteria will be used on both hits to correct items and false alarms to non-studied items. Participants who do not show the ability to discriminate old from new items, with false alarm rates equal to or greater than hit rates, will also be excluded. Finally, any participants that do not follow task or test directions will also be excluded from the study.

dependent.value: Recognition responses to test items will be the primary dependent variable. Recognition responses will be made using a Remember/Know judgment procedure, where participants must respond that they recollect the item (remember), the item is familiar to them (know), or they do not recognize the item (new). Dependent variables will include recognition responses computed using a hits minus false alarms correction and R/K responses will be analyses in raw format and recollection and familiarity estimates will be computed after Yonelinas (2002).

conditions.value:
In Experiment 1, study tasks (free recall vs. guessing vs. restudy) will be manipulated within-subjects. Task order will be randomized and counterbalanced in 2 versions. Fifty participants will be assigned to both counterbalanced versions of the experiment.

In Experiment 2, study tasks (free recall vs. guessing vs. restudy) will again be manipulated within-subjects. Study tasks will be blocked with 1 study task per block. Block order will be randomized and counterbalanced in 6 versions. Seventeen participants will be assigned to all 6 counterbalanced versions of the experiment

In Experiment 3, study tasks (free recall vs. guessing vs. restudy) will be manipulated between-subjects. List order will be randomized and counterbalanced in 2 versions of each condition, resulting in 6 versions of the experiment. Seventeen participants will be randomly assigned to all 6 counterbalanced versions of the experiment.

hypothesis.value:
This study will examine how task expectancy processes derived from repeated recall testing and guessing tasks influence recollection and familiarity in recognition memory. These experiments will replicate and extend the work of Huff, Yates and Balota (2018) who showed that task repetitions of recall testing and guessing increased correct recognition relative to completing a repeated restudy task (i.e., a retrieval-practice effect; Rowland, 2014). 

Experiment 1 will be a systematic replication of Huff et al. (2018; Experiment 1). Participants will be given instructions for all 3 tasks (free recall, guessing, and restudy) prior to any list presentation but will be unaware of which specific task they will be asked to complete and therefore would not have developed an expectancy for a given task. After the participant has been presented with the list of words to study, they will be given the instructions for the specific task they will need to complete. After 18 study/task trials, participants will then complete a final recognition test which will include R/K judgments for old words to provide estimates of recollection and familiarity. Based on Huff et al.’s previous work, we predict a reversed retrieval-practice effect in which restudy will produce a correct recognition advantage over testing and guessing tasks. Across all task types, recollection is expected to be greater for testing and guessing lists relative to restudy, and familiarity is expected to be greater for restudy relative to testing and guessing, demonstrating a tradeoff between recollection and familiarity. The recognition test will also contain critical items. We expect that false recognition will be lower for lists using the guessing task as this task requires participants to generate non-studied but related critical lures. Familiarity is also expected to be greater for critical items when compared to recollection across all task types and familiarity will be reduced as a result of the guessing task.

Experiment 2 will also manipulate task presentation within-subjects with the exception that now tasks will be repeated and blocked together in 3 separate blocks to encourage expectancy effects. Experiment 2 is a systematic replication of Huff et al. (2018; Experiment 4A/4B) in which they reported that testing and guessing improved final correct recognition relative to restudy (a retrieval-practice effect). Experiment 2 will have participants repeat tasks 6 times before completing a recognition test. Participants will also be presented with the specific instructions for the task they will be completing prior to list study. Overall, testing and guessing blocks are expected to show an increase in correct recognition of list items and a decrease in false recognition of critical items relative to restudy (patterns reported by Huff et al.). Again, recollection is expected to be greater for lists using both the testing and guessing tasks. Familiarity estimates are expected to be equivalent across all task types, as expectancy effects should not be strong enough after only 6 repetitions to significantly influence familiarity. As in Experiment 1, familiarity is expected to be greater compared to recollection for critical items across all task types.    

Experiment 3 will manipulate task type (free recall vs. guessing vs. restudy) between subjects. Participants will complete 18 repetitions of the same task to enhance the expectancy effects demonstrated in Experiment 2. Participants should demonstrate enhanced benefits of task expectancy due to the extensive repetitions of each task. Overall, correct recognition is expected to increase in the testing and guessing conditions relative to restudy, while false recognition is expected to decrease in these conditions. Recollection estimates are expected to increase for participants in the testing and guessing conditions compared to the restudy condition at an even greater rate than in Experiment 2, due to enhanced expectancy effects. Familiarity estimates are also expected to increase for participants in the testing and guessing conditions, but not to the extent of recollection. For all conditions, familiarity estimates are expected to be greater relative to recollection for false recognition of critical items. Familiarity estimates are expected to be greatest in the restudy condition and lowest in the guessing condition.

attributes.title: Religiosity and Relational Anxiety: A Cross-Denominational Study

q1.value: Religiosity and Relational Anxiety: A Cross-Denominational Study

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: There will be a negative relationship between intrinsic religiosity and trait anxiety
Hypothesis 2: There will be a negative relationship between intrinsic religiosity and relational anxiety
Hypothesis 3: The negative relationship between intrinsic religiosity and relational anxiety will be stronger for Protestant Christians than for Catholic Christians
Hypothesis 4: There will be a negative relationship between social trust and relational anxiety

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study is a between-subjects design. The independent variable is denominational affiliation, for which there is an unspecified number of levels. One level will be Catholic Protestants, and the other levels will be comprised of Protestant denominations or denominational groups to be established after data collection is complete. Participants will receive a survey comprised of four different metrics: Hoge’s 1972 Intrinsic Religious Motivation scale; a combination of the IPIP’s Hexaco and 16PF anxiety scales; Snell’s 1998 relational-anxiety subscale of the Relational Assessment Questionnaire; and a single-item used to assess social trust (Dingemans and Van Ingen, 2015). These scales are used to measure intrinsic religiosity, trait anxiety, relational anxiety, and social trust, respectively. Responses will be used to evaluate the relationships between these variables, as well as assess any denominational differences.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: There are two exclusion rules—respondents must be over 18 years of age, and respondents must have accurately responded to the two added items that ask for specific responses: i.e, “please select ‘strongly agree’”. Participants will be drawn from three different populations—a public population on Amazon Mechanical Turk (AMT); a population of undergraduate students at Olivet Nazarene University (ONU); and a population acquired by word-of-mouth using a Survey Monkey link, estimated to be comprised mostly of ONU students. Participants recruited via AMT will be paid $0.10 for survey completion. Participants acquired via undergraduate courses at ONU will be offered extra credit.

q13.value: It is estimated that 30 participants will be obtained in-person at Olivet Nazarene University, 100 participants will be obtained via Survey Monkey, and 1,000 participants will be obtained through Amazon Mechanical Turk. Subgroup differences will be explored before data analysis.

q14.value: The constraints for Amazon Mechanical Turk are budget; the constraints for in-person surveys at Olivet Nazarene University are time and personnel; and the constraints for Survey Monkey is time.

q15.value: Data collection will be terminated March 1, 2020.

question.value: This is a quasi-experimental study, so no variables will be manipulated.

This study will measure 4 variables: intrinsic religiosity, trait anxiety, relational anxiety, and social trust. 
Intrinsic religiosity will be assessed using Hoge’s (1972) Intrinsic Religiosity Scale. The scale asks participants to rate their level of agreement with 10 statements designed to measure whether the respondents view religion as an end in and of itself (intrinsically valuable) or a means to some other end (extrinsically valuable).The endpoints for this scale range from 1 = strongly disagree to 5 = strongly agree. 
Trait anxiety will be assessed using a combination of the IPIP’s HEXACO and 16PF anxiety scales (Goldberg et al., 2006). There are 11 items on this scale, including one screening item.  The endpoints for this scale range from 1 = strongly disagree to 5 = strongly agree, and the scale was designed to measure the propensity of respondents to become anxious across many different situations.
Relational anxiety will be assessed using the relational anxiety subscale from Snell’s (1998) Relational Assessment Questionnaire. There are 10 items on this scale, including one screening item. This scale was designed to measure how comfortable and open participants are with close, intimate relationships. The endpoints for this scale range from 1 = Not at all characteristic of me to 5 = Very characteristic of me
Social trust will be assessed using a single item as described by Dingemans and Van Ingen (2015). The item asks whether participants think “most people can be trusted” = 0, or “you can’t be too careful in dealing with people” = 1. 
The only covariate assessed will be trait anxiety in the relationship between relational anxiety and intrinsic religiosity.

Hypothesis 1: There will be a negative relationship between intrinsic religiosity and trait anxiety. Analysis: Pearson’s r. 
Hypothesis 2: There will be a negative relationship between intrinsic religiosity and relational anxiety. Analysis: Pearson’s r, ANCOVA (with trait anxiety as the covariate). 
Hypothesis 3: The negative relationship between intrinsic religiosity and relational anxiety will be stronger for Protestants than for Catholics. Analysis: z-test. 
Hypothesis 4: There will be a negative relationship between social trust and relational anxiety. Analysis: Point biserial coefficient or independent t-test.

q21.value: Each of the tests used to test my hypotheses will be one-tailed and significance will be evaluated at the .05 level.

q24.value: Demographic information (sex, ethnicity, age, relationship status, religion, denomination) will be collected, and exploratory analyses will assess the interaction of these variables with trait anxiety, intrinsic religiosity, relational anxiety, and social trust.

registration_responses.q1: Religiosity and Relational Anxiety: A Cross-Denominational Study
registration_responses.q4:
Hypothesis 1: There will be a negative relationship between intrinsic religiosity and trait anxiety
Hypothesis 2: There will be a negative relationship between intrinsic religiosity and relational anxiety
Hypothesis 3: The negative relationship between intrinsic religiosity and relational anxiety will be stronger for Protestant Christians than for Catholic Christians
Hypothesis 4: There will be a negative relationship between social trust and relational anxiety
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: It is estimated that 30 participants will be obtained in-person at Olivet Nazarene University, 100 participants will be obtained via Survey Monkey, and 1,000 participants will be obtained through Amazon Mechanical Turk. Subgroup differences will be explored before data analysis.
registration_responses.q14: The constraints for Amazon Mechanical Turk are budget; the constraints for in-person surveys at Olivet Nazarene University are time and personnel; and the constraints for Survey Monkey is time.
registration_responses.q15: Data collection will be terminated March 1, 2020.
registration_responses.q21: Each of the tests used to test my hypotheses will be one-tailed and significance will be evaluated at the .05 level.
registration_responses.q24: Demographic information (sex, ethnicity, age, relationship status, religion, denomination) will be collected, and exploratory analyses will assess the interaction of these variables with trait anxiety, intrinsic religiosity, relational anxiety, and social trust.
registration_responses.q8.question: This study is a between-subjects design. The independent variable is denominational affiliation, for which there is an unspecified number of levels. One level will be Catholic Protestants, and the other levels will be comprised of Protestant denominations or denominational groups to be established after data collection is complete. Participants will receive a survey comprised of four different metrics: Hoge’s 1972 Intrinsic Religious Motivation scale; a combination of the IPIP’s Hexaco and 16PF anxiety scales; Snell’s 1998 relational-anxiety subscale of the Relational Assessment Questionnaire; and a single-item used to assess social trust (Dingemans and Van Ingen, 2015). These scales are used to measure intrinsic religiosity, trait anxiety, relational anxiety, and social trust, respectively. Responses will be used to evaluate the relationships between these variables, as well as assess any denominational differences.
registration_responses.q12.question: There are two exclusion rules—respondents must be over 18 years of age, and respondents must have accurately responded to the two added items that ask for specific responses: i.e, “please select ‘strongly agree’”. Participants will be drawn from three different populations—a public population on Amazon Mechanical Turk (AMT); a population of undergraduate students at Olivet Nazarene University (ONU); and a population acquired by word-of-mouth using a Survey Monkey link, estimated to be comprised mostly of ONU students. Participants recruited via AMT will be paid $0.10 for survey completion. Participants acquired via undergraduate courses at ONU will be offered extra credit.
registration_responses.q16.question: This is a quasi-experimental study, so no variables will be manipulated.
registration_responses.q17.question:
This study will measure 4 variables: intrinsic religiosity, trait anxiety, relational anxiety, and social trust. 
Intrinsic religiosity will be assessed using Hoge’s (1972) Intrinsic Religiosity Scale. The scale asks participants to rate their level of agreement with 10 statements designed to measure whether the respondents view religion as an end in and of itself (intrinsically valuable) or a means to some other end (extrinsically valuable).The endpoints for this scale range from 1 = strongly disagree to 5 = strongly agree. 
Trait anxiety will be assessed using a combination of the IPIP’s HEXACO and 16PF anxiety scales (Goldberg et al., 2006). There are 11 items on this scale, including one screening item.  The endpoints for this scale range from 1 = strongly disagree to 5 = strongly agree, and the scale was designed to measure the propensity of respondents to become anxious across many different situations.
Relational anxiety will be assessed using the relational anxiety subscale from Snell’s (1998) Relational Assessment Questionnaire. There are 10 items on this scale, including one screening item. This scale was designed to measure how comfortable and open participants are with close, intimate relationships. The endpoints for this scale range from 1 = Not at all characteristic of me to 5 = Very characteristic of me
Social trust will be assessed using a single item as described by Dingemans and Van Ingen (2015). The item asks whether participants think “most people can be trusted” = 0, or “you can’t be too careful in dealing with people” = 1. 
The only covariate assessed will be trait anxiety in the relationship between relational anxiety and intrinsic religiosity.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Hypothesis 1: There will be a negative relationship between intrinsic religiosity and trait anxiety. Analysis: Pearson’s r. 
Hypothesis 2: There will be a negative relationship between intrinsic religiosity and relational anxiety. Analysis: Pearson’s r, ANCOVA (with trait anxiety as the covariate). 
Hypothesis 3: The negative relationship between intrinsic religiosity and relational anxiety will be stronger for Protestants than for Catholics. Analysis: z-test. 
Hypothesis 4: There will be a negative relationship between social trust and relational anxiety. Analysis: Point biserial coefficient or independent t-test.

attributes.title: Complementary analysis on  Halfmann, E., Bredehöft, J., & Häusser, J. A. (2020) dataset

q1.value: Complementary analysis on Halfmann, E., Bredehöft, J., & Häusser, J. A. (2020) dataset

q3.value:
The study has already been conducted : Halfmann, E., Bredehöft, J., & Häusser, J. A. (2020). Replicating roaches: A preregistered direct replication of zajonc, heingartner, and herman’s (1969) social-facilitation study. Psychological Science, 095679762090210. https://doi.org/10.1177/0956797620902101. This pre-registration is only about complementary analyses on the original dataset.

As the authors write : "The major conclusion presented by Zajonc et al. was that, as they predicted, task difficulty moderated the effect of an audience, that is, it led to social facilitation in simple tasks and led to social inhibition in complex tasks.". The authors used 10 trials by animal in their experiment. However, we can  hypothesise that a "complex" task (i.e. the maze) repeated 10 times will not be complex anymore for the last trials.

q4.value: I want to test the Audience × Task Difficulty interaction only on the first trials of the experiment. The hypothesis is that social facilitation will be observed in the simple task and social inhibition in the complex task.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The design is already described in the original study.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: Everything is already described in the original study.
Everything is already described in the original study.

Replicating roaches: A preregistered direct replication of zajonc, heingartner, and herman’s (1969) social-facilitation study. Psychological Science, 095679762090210. https://doi.org/10.1177/0956797620902101. This pre-registration is only about complementary analyses on the original dataset.

As the authors write : "The major conclusion presented by Zajonc et al. was that, as they predicted, task difficulty moderated the effect of an audience, that is, it led to social facilitation in simple tasks and led to social inhibition in complex tasks.". The authors used 10 trials by animal in their experiment. However, we can  hypothesise that a "complex" task (i.e. the maze) repeated 10 times will not be complex anymore for the last trials.
